revision.text:
'''Airborne Launch Assist Space Access''', or '''DARPA ALASA''' is a canceled program of the [[Federal government of the United States|US]] defense technology agency [[DARPA]] "designed to produce a rocket capable of launching a 100-pound satellite into low Earth orbit for less than $1 million."<ref name=pa20120702/> The program was conceived, then announced in 2011, and funded [[New product development|development]] work began in 2012. The project was terminated in late 2015.
==Background== Traditional launch methods of satellites are too costly to put small payloads into orbit without a larger payload accompanying it to make the launch worth the expense. Current launches of sub-100-pound satellites are performed as "piggyback payloads" on launches of much larger spacecraft, usually headed for [[geostationary orbit]], and are released at the altitude of the primary payload. In addition, range costs of operating from ground-based infrastructure have escalated as they have aged, accounting for up to 35 percent of the launch cost. This restricts the number of light satellite launches to 10-12 per year, which could be increased if small payloads could be launched into space affordably and without ground range constraints. Air-launching satellites was first seriously considered during the 1950s and 1960s, but small payloads in the 100-pound class at the time did not have effective capabilities, so the method was overlooked. The first air-launched rocket to put a satellite into orbit was the [[Orbital Sciences Corporation]] [[Pegasus (rocket)|Pegasus]], which did it on 13 June 1990; however, it is currently deployed from a heavily modified and expensive [[Lockheed L-1011]] airliner. The ALASA program's objective is to use an unmodified aircraft platform (except for software) that does not have to be dedicated to the mission to place a 100 lb satellite into orbit that requires only 24 hours notice to integrate and launch the payload, with the ability to re-plan the launch in flight and relocate the aircraft to any civilian airport or military airfield in a crisis situation, while using onboard [[GPS]]/inertial position reporting rather than ground-based radar tracking.<ref>[http://aviationweek.com/awin/darpa-revisits-air-launch-focus-cost Darpa Revisits Air Launch With Focus On Cost] - Aviationweek.com, 25 July 2012</ref>
==History== A program solicitation was announced in 2011, and six companies were awarded contracts in July 2012. The six awardees who signed phase 1 contracts with DARPA included:<ref name=pa20120702> {{cite news |last=Messier|first=Doug |title=DARPA Awards 6 Small Airborne Launch Vehicle Contracts |url=http://www.parabolicarc.com/2012/07/02/darpa-awards-6-small-airborne-launch-vehicle-contracts/ |accessdate=2012-11-29 |newspaper=Parabolic Arc |date=2012-07-02 }}</ref> * [[Boeing]]– system concept * [[Lockheed Martin]] – design utilizes a "tactical aircraft to provide a high energy-state, [[Reusable launch vehicle|reusable]] [[first stage (rocketry)|first stage]], enabling launches from bases worldwide"<ref name=pa20120702/> * [[Northrop Grumman]] * [[Space Information Laboratories]] – is "providing three key enabling technologies that could be used in multiple launch systems, including [[GPS]] Metric Track, Autonomous Flight Termination System (AFTS) and Space Based Range to reduce range launch cost."<ref name=pa20120702/> * [[Ventions]] – [[second stage]] [[launch vehicle]] * [[Virgin Galactic]] – utilizes its existing [[WhiteKnight2]] carrier aircraft
In the first phase, Boeing, Lockheed Martin and Virgin Galactic were funded to explore different ALASA system concepts while Northrop Grumman, Space Information Laboratories and Ventions were contracted to work on enabling technologies that could be used by any or all of the system teams.<ref name=aw20120625> {{cite news |last=Warwick|first=Graham |title=Darpa Revisits Air Launch With Focus On Cost |url=http://www.aviationweek.com/Article.aspx?id=/article-xml/AW_06_25_2012_p33-469762.xml |accessdate=2012-11-29 |newspaper=Aviation Week |date=2012-06-25 }}</ref>
In December 2012, DARPA announced that the ALASA program would provide the [[launch vehicle]] booster for another DARPA [[DARPA SeeMe program|program]] that is intending to release a "[[Satellite constellation|constellation]] of 24 [[Microsatellite (spaceflight)|micro-satellites]] (~{{convert|20|kg}} range) each with 1-meter imaging [[Satellite imagery|resolution]]."<ref name=nsw20121219> {{cite news |last=Lindsey|first=Clark |title=DARPA developing microsat constellation orbited with air-launch system |url=http://www.newspacewatch.com/articles/darpa-developing-microsat-constellation-orbited-with-air-launch-system.html |accessdate=2012-12-22 |newspaper=NewSpace Watch |date=2012-12-19 |subscription=yes }}</ref>
In May 2013, DARPA requested {{US$|40 million}} for a second year of ALASA program funding in spring 2013.<ref name=sn20130517>{{cite news|last=Ferster|first=Warren|title=DARPA Cancels Formation-flying Satellite Demo|url=http://www.spacenews.com/article/military-space/35375darpa-cancels-formation-flying-satellite-demo|accessdate=2013-11-01|newspaper=Space News|date=2013-05-17}}</ref>
In March 2014, Boeing won the large {{USD|32–104 million}} phase 2 ALASA contract from DARPA.<ref>[http://www.spacenews.com/article/military-space/39967darpa-picks-boeing-to-demonstrate-airborne-launcher-concept DARPA Picks Boeing To Demonstrate Airborne Launcher Concept | SpaceNews.com<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> Boeing will use their [[McDonnell Douglas F-15E Strike Eagle|F-15E Strike Eagle]] fighter to carry the ALASA rocket up to {{convert|12,000|m|ft|abbr=on}}, then release the {{convert|7.3|m|ft|abbr=on}} rocket to ignite and carry itself into orbit. Using a modified fighter-jet to launch the rocket would increase satellite launch sites from four locations ([[Cape Canaveral Air Force Station]], Florida; [[Vandenberg Air Force Base]], California; [[Wallops Flight Facility]], Virginia; and [[Kodiak Island]], Alaska) to any available runway. The cost to put a {{convert|45|kg|lb|abbr=on}} microsatellite into orbit is targeted at $1 million, a decrease of 66 percent. A demonstration launch was hoped for in FY 2015.<ref>[http://www.spacenews.com/article/military-space/40023boeing-targets-66-percent-launch-cost-reduction-with-alasa Boeing Targets 66 Percent Launch Cost Reduction with ALASA] - Spacenews.com, 28 March 2014</ref>
The F-15E launch vehicle would have required no modifications to launch the ALASA payload, not even software, because the rocket will use the same communications protocols as a typically mounted weapons system. This enables the aircraft to continue flying other missions as a cost benefit over being specialized. The rocket will also feature new design technologies to lower complexity and costs. It will be powered by a monopropellant, a combination of [[nitrous oxide]] and [[acetylene]], and mixed together in one propellant tank slightly below room temperature; the propellant choice is a dramatic simplification of the complexity of the rocket vehicle. Rocket design is also unconventional, mounting the four engines for the first stage at the front rather than rear. DARPA plans to develop a second, smaller launch system called the Small Air Launch Vehicle to Orbit (SALVO) to understand operations cost, demonstrate new technologies like battery-powered pumps for the rocket’s engines, and provide overall program before ALASA is launched. SALVO was planned to launch in spring 2015, six to nine months before the first ALASA flight in late 2015. 12 flights were to be conducted through mid-2016 from [[Eglin Air Force Base]], Florida over the Atlantic Ocean.<ref>[http://www.thespacereview.com/article/2543/1 Air launch, big and small] - Thespacereview.com, 30 June 2014</ref>
By June 2015, DARPA and the Air Force had reportedly began SALVO flights, potentially having already commenced them to counter Chinese and Russian electronic and infrared surveillance; this could mean ALASA would give the U.S. a "stealth satellite launch" capability.<ref>[http://defensesystems.com/Articles/2015/06/19/DARPA-Air-Force-SALVO-cubesat-launch.aspx Airborne 'stealth launch' of CubeSat said to be underway] - Defensesystems.com, 19 June 2015</ref>
==Budget== The program had a budget of "{{US$|46 million}} for the 18-month first phase through September 2013, when [DARPA] planned another competition to select at least one team to conduct up to 36 launches in 2015 [in order to] to demonstrate [the Alasa system] at a persuasive scale."<ref name=aw20120625/> {{US$|40 million}} has been requested for the second year.<ref name=sn20130517/>
==Competition== After DARPA announced in December 2012 that the ALASA air-launched [[Microsatellite launch vehicle|microsat launch vehicle]] would be chosen to launch the [[DARPA SeeMe program]] [[Microsatellite (spaceflight)|micro-satellites]], some questions arose as to why other [[Private spaceflight|commercial]] options currently in development were not considered, such as the [[Virgin Galactic]] [[LauncherOne]] and the [[XCOR Aerospace]] [[Lynx (spacecraft)#Mark III|Lynx]].<ref name=nsw20121219/>
==Termination== DARPA terminated the program in late 2015, due to safety concerns with the unique monopropellant, NA-7, which exploded in two ground tests. It was reported that development of the propellant would continue, as would efforts to apply technologies developed in the program.<ref> {{cite web |url=http://spacenews.com/darpa-airborne-launcher-effort-falters |author=Mike Gruss |title=DARPA Scraps Plan To Launch Small Sats from F-15 Fighter Jet |publisher=spacenews.com |date=30 Nov 2015 |accessdate=1 Dec 2015 }} </ref>
==See also== * [[Air launch to orbit]] * [[XS-1 (spacecraft)]]
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20121119081400/http://www.darpa.mil/Our_Work/TTO/Programs/Airborne_Launch_Assist_Space_Access_%28ALASA%29.aspx DARPA ALASA Program page] at the Tactical Technology Office website *[https://www.fbo.gov/index?s=opportunity&mode=form&id=0ad6397acb2e17d4666acfe227d1b82b&tab=core&_cview=1 ALASA contract solicitation and awards] – FedBizOpps.gov
{{Use American English|date=January 2014}}
[[Category:DARPA]] [[Category:Science and technology in the United States]] [[Category:Air launch to orbit]] [[Category:Research projects]] [[Category:Microsatellite launch vehicles]] [[Category:Proposed space launch vehicles]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox book | name = Chaos: Making a New Science | title_orig = | translator = | image = Chaos Gleick OReB.jpg | caption = 20th-anniversary edition | author = [[James Gleick]] | cover_artist = | country = United States | language = English | series = | genre = [[Popular science]] | publisher = [[Viking Books]] | release_date = October 29, 1987 | media_type = Print, e-book | pages = 400 pp. | isbn = 0-7493-8606-1 | oclc = 59649776 | congress = Q172.5.C45 G54 1987 | preceded_by = | followed_by = Nature's Chaos }}
'''''Chaos: Making a New Science''''' is a debut non-fiction book by [[James Gleick]] that initially introduced the principles and early development of the [[chaos theory]] to the public.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.imho.com/grae/chaos/chaos.html |title=Chaos Theory: A Brief Introduction |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130805120146/http://www.imho.com/grae/chaos/chaos.html |archivedate=August 5, 2013 }} {{dead link|date=May 2017}}</ref> It was a finalist for the [[National Book Award]]<ref>{{cite web|last=Gleick|first=James|title=National Book Awards - 1987|url=https://www.nationalbook.org/awards-prizes/national-book-awards-1987|work=Chaos: Making a New Science|publisher=National Book Foundation|accessdate=28 May 2011}}</ref> and the [[Pulitzer Prize]]<ref>{{cite web|last=Gleick|first=James|title=1988 Finalists|url=http://www.pulitzer.org/finalists/1988|work=Chaos:Making a new Science|publisher=[[The Pulitzer Prizes]]|accessdate=28 May 2011}}</ref> in 1987, and was shortlisted for the [[Royal Society Prizes for Science Books|Science Book Prize]] in 1989.<ref>{{cite web|last=Gleick|first=James|title=Royal Society Prize for Science Books. Shortlisted Entries|url=http://royalsociety.org/awards/science-books/all-shortlisted/|work=Chaos|publisher=[[The Royal Society]]|accessdate=3 June 2011}}</ref> The book was published on October 29, 1987 by [[Viking Books]].
==Overview== The first popular book about chaos theory, it describes the [[Mandelbrot set]], [[Julia set]]s, and [[Lorenz attractor]]s without using complicated mathematics. It portrays the efforts of dozens of scientists whose separate work contributed to the developing field. The text remains in print and is widely used as an introduction to the topic for the mathematical layperson. An enhanced ebook edition was released by Open Road Media in 2011, adding embedded video and hyperlinked notes.<ref>{{cite web|last=Maynard|first=Andrew|title=James Gleick’s Chaos – the enhanced edition|url=http://2020science.org/2011/04/09/james-gleicks-chaos-the-enhanced-edition/|work=Review|publisher=2020 Science|accessdate=18 August 2011}}</ref>
==Reception== [[Robert Sapolsky]] said that, "Chaos is the first book since ''[[Baby Beluga]]'' where I've gotten to the last page and immediately started reading it over again from the front."<ref>https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NNnIGh9g6fA&t=47m20s</ref>
[[Freeman Dyson]] critiqued the book for omitting the earlier work of Dame [[Mary L. Cartwright]] and [[J. E. Littlewood]], which he credits as forming the foundation of chaos theory, but also praised it as a popular account.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Frenkel|first1=Karen A.|title=Why Aren't More Women Physicists?|url=https://www.scientificamerican.com/article/why-arent-more-women-phys/|website=Scientific American|accessdate=11 July 2017|pages=90–92|language=en|doi=10.1038/scientificamerican0207-90|date=1 February 2007|bibcode = 2007SciAm.296b..90F }}</ref>
==References== <references/>
==External links== *[http://www.mountainman.com.au/chaos_03.htm Excerpts] *[http://www.around.com/chaos.html Selection from the prologue] *[http://www.around.com/ Website of James Gleick]
{{Fractals}}
[[Category:Physics books]] [[Category:1987 books]] [[Category:Popular science books]] [[Category:Chaos theory]]

revision.text:
The '''DeLong Star Ruby''', a {{convert|100.32|carat|g|adj=on}} oval [[cabochon]] [[asterism (gemmology)|star ruby]], was discovered in [[Burma]] in the 1930s.<ref name=Sofianides>{{cite book|last=Sofianides|first=Anna S.|title=Gems & Crystals from the American Museum of Natural History|year=1990|publisher=Simon and Schuster|location=New York|isbn=0-671-68704-2|page=52|author2=George E. Harlow}}</ref> It was sold by Martin Ehrmann to Edith Haggin DeLong for {{Currency|21400}}, who then donated it to the [[American Museum of Natural History]] in [[New York City]] in 1937.
On October 29, 1964, the DeLong star ruby was one of a number of precious gems stolen in a notorious jewelry heist by [[Jack Roland Murphy]] and two accomplices. Some of the stolen gems (notably, the [[Star of India (gem)|Star of India]] and the Midnight Star) were recovered in a bus depot locker in January 1965; however, the DeLong ruby was not among them.<ref name=Sosin>{{cite news|last=Sosin|first=Milt|title=Star of India Found in Miami Bus Depot|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=ebQzAAAAIBAJ&sjid=auoFAAAAIBAJ&pg=2470,2260128&hl=en|accessdate=24 October 2012|newspaper=The Miami News|date=January 8, 1965}}</ref> After months of negotiation, the unknown holder of the ruby agreed, through third parties, to ransom it for $25,000. The ransom was paid by wealthy Florida businessman [[John D. MacArthur]] and he was present on September 2, 1965, when the ruby was recovered at the designated drop off site: a phone booth at a [[service plaza]] on the [[Sunshine State Parkway]] near [[Palm Beach, Florida]].<ref name=Preston>{{cite book|last=Preston|first=Douglas J.|title=Dinosaurs in the Attic|year=1986|publisher=St. Martin's Press|location=New York|isbn=0-312-21098-1|pages=210–218}}</ref><ref>[http://archives.chicagotribune.com/1965/09/03/ "$140,000 RUBY RANSOMED"], ''Chicago Tribune'', September 3, 1965, p1</ref>
==References== <references/>
==External links== *[http://www.starruby.in/delong-star-ruby.html The DeLong Star Ruby] *[https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=2209&dat=19650903&id=SiNbAAAAIBAJ&sjid=_U4NAAAAIBAJ&pg=5916,335846 100-Carat Delong Star Ruby Recovered Near Palm Beach]
[[Category:Individual rubies]] [[Category:Individual thefts]]

{{italic title}} {{Infobox spaceflight | name = ''EPOXI'' | image = PIA02109.jpg | image_caption = The [[Deep Impact (spacecraft)|Deep Impact]] spacecraft at the JPL in July 2004. | image_alt = A spacecraft under construction hangs in the hallway of a laboratory as a scientist, clothed in a white protective suit, attaches scientific instruments to the spacecraft bus. | image_size = 300 | mission_type = *Flyby ([[85P/Boethin]]{{dot}}[[103P/Hartley]]{{dot}}[[(163249) 2002 GT]]) *[[Space observatory]] | operator = [[NASA]] | COSPAR_ID = 2005-001A | website = {{url|http://epoxi.umd.edu}} | mission_duration = 8 years, 18 days | distance_travelled = | spacecraft = ''[[Deep Impact (spacecraft)|Deep Impact]]'' | manufacturer = [[Jet Propulsion Laboratory|JPL]]{{dot}}[[Ball Aerospace & Technologies Corp.|Ball Aerospace]]{{dot}}[[University of Maryland, College Park|University of Maryland]] | launch_mass = {{convert|650|kg|lb|abbr=on}} | dimensions = | power = 620.0 [[watt|W]] | entered_service = {{start date|2005|07|21}}
({{Age in years, months and days|year=2005|month=07|day=21}} ago) | last_contact = {{start date|2013|08|08}}
({{Age in years, months and days|year=2013|month=08|day=08}} ago) |interplanetary = {{Infobox spaceflight/IP |type = flyby |object = [[103P/Hartley|Hartley 2]] |arrival_date = {{start date|2010|11|04}} ~03:00 [[Coordinated Universal Time|UTC]]
({{Age in years, months and days|year=2010|month=11|day=04}} ago) |distance = {{convert|694|km|mi}} }} | insignia = EPOXI Mission Patch.png | insignia_caption = Official insignia for the re-targeted ''DIXI'' mission to Hartley 2 | insignia_alt = A circle with a blue border encloses an image of a spacecraft on approach to a comet. The words "EPOXI Mission" and "Deep Impact Extended Investigation" are written along the border of the image. | insignia_size = 200px }} '''''EPOXI''''' is a compilation of [[NASA]] [[Discovery program]] missions led by the [[University of Maryland, College Park|University of Maryland]] and [[principal investigator]] [[Michael A'Hearn]], with co-operation from the [[Jet Propulsion Laboratory]] and [[Ball Aerospace & Technologies Corp.|Ball Aerospace]]. ''EPOXI'' uses the ''[[Deep Impact (spacecraft)|Deep Impact]]'' spacecraft in a campaign consisting two missions: the '''''Deep Impact Extended Investigation''''' (DIXI) and '''''Extrasolar Planet Observation and Characterization''''' (EPOCh). ''DIXI'' aimed to send the ''Deep Impact'' spacecraft on a flyby of another comet, after its primary mission was completed in July 2005, while ''EPOCh'' saw the spacecraft's photographic instruments as a [[space observatory]], studying [[extrasolar planets]].{{Cite press| url=http://www.nasa.gov/home/hqnews/2007/jul/HQ_07147_Discovery_missions.html| title=NASA Gives Two Successful Spacecraft New Assignments| date=July 3, 2007| publisher=[[NASA]]| accessdate=7 August 2009}}{{Cite press| url=http://www.nasa.gov/home/hqnews/2007/dec/HQ_07279_EPOXI_mission_to_comet_Hartley.html| title=NASA Sends Spacecraft on Mission to Comet Hartley 2| publisher=[[NASA]]| date=Dec 13, 2007| accessdate=7 August 2009}}{{Cite press| url=http://www.newsdesk.umd.edu/scitech/release.cfm?ArticleID=1564| title=Deep Impact Extended Mission Heads for Comet Hartley 2| publisher=[[University of Maryland, College Park|University of Maryland]]| date=December 13, 2007| accessdate=7 August 2009}} ''DIXI'' successfully sent the ''Deep Impact'' spacecraft on a flyby of comet [[103P/Hartley|Hartley 2]] on November 4, 2010, revealing a "hyperactive, small and feisty" comet, after three [[gravity assist]]s from [[Earth]] in December 2007, December 2008 and June 2010. The ''DIXI'' mission was not without problems, however; the spacecraft had initially been targeted for a December 5, 2008 flyby of comet [[85P/Boethin|Boethin]], though, the comet could not be located, and was later declared a [[lost comet]], prompting mission planners to reorganize a flyby of an alternative target, Hartley 2. After its flyby of Hartley 2, the spacecraft was also set to make a close flyby of the [[Apollo asteroid]] [[(163249) 2002 GT]] in 2020. The mission was suspended altogether, however, after contact with the spacecraft was suddenly lost in August 2013 and attempts to re-establish contact in the month following had failed.[http://www.abc.net.au/news/2013-09-21/nasa-calls-off-search-for-deep-impact-comet-probe/4972930 NASA calls off search for lost Deep Impact comet probe] - Australian Broadcasting Corporation - Retrieved September 21, 2013. Mission scientists theorized that a [[Year 2000 problem|Y2K]]-like problem had plagued the spacecraft's software. == Mission == [[File:Hartley2jets2 epoxi big.jpg|thumb|EPOXI mission observation of Hartley 2's jets]] The ''[[Deep Impact (spacecraft)|Deep Impact]]'' mission was finished with the visit to comet [[Tempel 1]]. But the spacecraft still had plenty of maneuvering fuel left, so NASA approved a second mission, called EPOXI (Extrasolar Planet Observation and Deep Impact Extended Investigation), which included a visit to a second comet (DIXI component) as well as observations of extrasolar planets (EPOCh component). ===Comet Boethin lost=== On July 21, 2005, ''Deep Impact'' executed a trajectory correction maneuver that placed the spacecraft on course to fly past Earth on December 31, 2007. The maneuver allowed the spacecraft to use Earth's gravity to begin a new mission in a path towards another comet. In January 2008 ''Deep Impact'' began studying the stars with several known [[extrasolar planet]]s in an attempt to find other such stars nearby. The larger of the spacecraft's two telescopes attempts to find the planets using the [[Methods of detecting extrasolar planets#Transit method|transit method]].{{cite web | title=Science Daily |work=Deep Impact Mission: Aiming For Close-ups Of Extrasolar Planets |url=https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2007/04/070410120957.htm| accessdate=June 3, 2007}} The initial plan was for a December 5, 2008 flyby of [[Comet Boethin]], with the spacecraft coming within {{convert|435|mi|km}}. The spacecraft did not carry a second impactor to collide with the comet and would observe the comet to compare it to various characteristics found on [[9P/Tempel]]. A'Hearn, the ''Deep Impact'' team leader reflected on the upcoming project at that time: "We propose to direct the spacecraft for a flyby of Comet Boethin to investigate whether the results found at Comet Tempel 1 are unique or are also found on other comets."{{cite web | title=Skymania News |work=Deep Impact will fly to new comet|url=http://skymania.com/wp/2006/11/deep-impact-will-fly-to-new-comet.html| accessdate=June 12, 2007}} He explained that the mission would provide only about half of the information collected during the collision with Tempel 1 but at a fraction of the cost. (EPOXI’s low mission cost of $40 million is achieved by reusing the existing Deep Impact spacecraft.) ''Deep Impact'' would use its [[spectrometer]] to study the comet's surface composition and its telescopes for viewing the surface features. [[File:EPOXI moon transits Earth.gif|thumb|right|Animation of the Moon [[Astronomical transit|transiting]] the Earth on 28–29 May 2008 by EPOXI.]] However, as the Earth gravity assist approached, astronomers were unable to locate Comet Boethin, which is too faint to be observed. Consequently, its orbit could not be calculated with sufficient precision to permit a flyby. Instead, the team decided to send ''Deep Impact'' to comet [[103P/Hartley]] requiring an extra two years. NASA approved the additional funding required and retargeted the spacecraft.[http://epoxi.umd.edu/1mission/status.shtml EPOXI Mission Status] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101115215854/http://epoxi.umd.edu/1mission/status.shtml |date=2010-11-15 }}, NASA/University of Maryland, December 2, 2007. Mission controllers at the Jet Propulsion Laboratory began redirecting EPOXI on November 1, 2007. They commanded the spacecraft to perform a three-minute rocket burn that changed the spacecraft's velocity. EPOXI’s new trajectory set the stage for three Earth flybys, the first on December 31, 2007. This placed the spacecraft into an orbital "holding pattern" so that it could encounter comet 103P/Hartley in 2010. "It's exciting that we can send the ''Deep Impact'' spacecraft on a new mission that combines two totally independent science investigations, both of which can help us better understand how solar systems form and evolve," said in December 2007 ''Deep Impact'' leader and University of Maryland astronomer [[Michael A'Hearn]] who is principal investigator for both the overall EPOXI mission and its DIXI component. In June 2009,[http://epoxi.umd.edu/2science/hydratedmoon.shtml Deep Impact and Other Spacecraft Find Clear Evidence of Water on Moon: Thin layer of surface 'dew' appears to form, then dissipate each day] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20120717034554/http://epoxi.umd.edu/2science/hydratedmoon.shtml |date=2012-07-17 }} EPOXI's spectrometer scanned the Moon on its way to Hartley, and discovered traces of "water or hydroxyl", confirming a [[Moon Mineralogy Mapper]] observation — a discovery announced in late September, 2009.[http://sciencenow.sciencemag.org/cgi/content/full/2009/924/1 Science, ''A Whiff of Water Found on the Moon''] === EPOCh === Before the 2008 flyby to re-orient for the comet 103P/Hartley encounter, the spacecraft used High Resolution Instrument, the larger of its two telescopes, to perform photometric observations of previously discovered transiting [[extrasolar planet]]s from January to August 2008.{{cite web |title=EPOXI Mission Status Reports |url=http://epoxi.umd.edu/1mission/status.shtml |accessdate=2009-03-07 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101115215854/http://epoxi.umd.edu/1mission/status.shtml |archivedate=2010-11-15 |df= }} The goal of [[photometry (astronomy)|photometric]] observations is to measure the quantity of light, not necessarily resolve an image. An aberration in the primary mirror of the HRI {{cite web |title=Beyond Deep Impact: Possible Targets After Fireworks |url=http://www.space.com/businesstechnology/050629_deep_impact_beyond.html |accessdate=2010-03-01}} allowed the HRI to spread the light from observations over more pixels without saturating the CCD, effectively obtaining better data. A total of 198,434 images were exposed.Rieber, R., Sharrow, & Robert. (2009). The Contingency of Success: Operations for Deep Impact's Planet Hunt. IEEE Aerospace Conference. Big Sky, MT url=https://trs.jpl.nasa.gov/handle/2014/45329 EPOCh's goals were to study the physical properties of giant planets and search for rings, moons and planets{{cite web |title=Sarah Ballard: Preliminary Results from the NASA EPOXI Mission |format=Mov |url=http://epoxi.umd.edu/2science/index.shtml |accessdate=2009-03-07 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20121215033322/http://epoxi.umd.edu/2science/index.shtml |archivedate=2012-12-15 |df= }} (at 2 minutes 20 seconds in video) as small as three Earth masses.{{cite web |title=EPOXI Mission Science |url=http://epoxi.umd.edu/2science/index.shtml |accessdate=2009-03-07 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20121215033322/http://epoxi.umd.edu/2science/index.shtml |archivedate=2012-12-15 |df= }} It also looked at Earth as though it were an extrasolar planet to provide data that could characterize Earth-type planets for future missions, and it imaged the Earth over 24 hours to capture the Moon passing in front on 2008-05-29. {| class="toccolours sortable" border=1 cellspacing=0 cellpadding=2 align=center style="text-align:center; border-collapse:collapse; margin-left: 0; margin-right: auto;" |+Planetary systems observed |- bgcolor="#a0b0ff" ! [[Star]] ! [[Constellation]] ! [[Stellar distance|Distance]] ([[light year|ly]]) ! [[Planet]] |- | [[XO-2 (star)|XO-2]] || [[Lynx (constellation)|Lynx]] || 486 | [[XO-2b|b]] |- | [[Gliese 436]] || [[Leo (constellation)|Leo]] || 33.48 | [[Gliese 436 b|b]] |- | [[BD+36°2593]] || [[Boötes]] || 1010 | [[HAT-P-4b]] |- | [[GSC 03089-00929]] || [[Hercules (constellation)|Hercules]] || 1300 | [[TrES-3]] |- | [[WASP-3]] || [[Lyra (constellation)|Lyra]] || 727 | [[WASP-3b|b]] |- | [[GSC 03549-02811]] || [[Draco (constellation)|Draco]] || 718 | [[TrES-2]] |- | [[HAT-P-7b|HAT-P-7]] || [[Cygnus (constellation)|Cygnus]] || 1044 | [[HAT-P-7b|b]] |} === Comet flyby === [[File:Animation of Deep Impact trajectory.gif|thumb|right|Animation of Deep Impact{{'s}} trajectory from 12 January 2005 to 8 August 2013
{{legend2|magenta| Deep Impact 1}} {{legend2|lime|[[Tempel 1]]}} {{legend2|royalblue|[[Earth]]}} {{legend2|cyan|[[103P/Hartley]]}}]] {{see also|103P/Hartley}} [[Image:Comet Hartley 2.jpg|thumb|right|The nucleus of comet 103P/Hartley measuring approximately 2 kilometers in length and .4 kilometers at its most narrow portion or neck. Jets can be seen streaming out of the nucleus.]] The spacecraft used Earth's gravity for the second gravity assist in December 2008 and made two distant flybys of Earth in June and December 2009. On May 30, 2010 it successfully fired its engines for an 11.3 second trajectory correction maneuver, for a velocity change (ΔV) of {{convert|0.1|m/s|mph|sp=us}}, in preparation for the third Earth flyby on June 27. Observations of 103P/Hartley began on September 5 and ended November 25, 2010.{{cite web |url=http://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/epoxi/epoxi20100528.html |title=NASA Spacecraft Burns for Home, Then Comet |publisher=NASA}} For a diagram of the EPOXI solar orbits see [https://web.archive.org/web/20100905134548/http://epoxi.umd.edu/3gallery/DIXI_path_full.shtml here]. [[File:495452main epoxi-3-4x3 946-710.jpg|150px|thumb|left|Another view of the comet, taken near closest approach.]] The mission's closest approach to 103P/Hartley occurred at 10 am EDT on 4 November 2010, passing to within {{convert|694|km|mi|sp=us}} of this small comet. The flyby speed was 12.3 km/s. The spacecraft employed the same suite of three science instruments—two telescopes and an infrared spectrometer—that the Deep Impact spacecraft used during its prime mission to guide an impactor into comet Tempel 1 in July 2005 and observe the results.{{Cite journal | last1 = A'Hearn | first1 = M. F. |authorlink1=Michael A'Hearn | last2 = Belton | first2 = M. J. S. | last3 = Delamere | first3 = W. A. | last4 = Feaga | first4 = L. M. | last5 = Hampton | first5 = D. | last6 = Kissel | first6 = J. | last7 = Klaasen | first7 = K. P. | last8 = McFadden | first8 = L. A. | last9 = Meech | first9 = K. J. | last10 = Melosh | first10 = H. J. | last11 = Schultz | first11 = P. H. | last12 = Sunshine | first12 = J. M. | last13 = Thomas | first13 = P. C. | last14 = Veverka | first14 = J. | last15 = Wellnitz | first15 = D. D. | last16 = Yeomans | first16 = D. K. | last17 = Besse | first17 = S. | last18 = Bodewits | first18 = D. | last19 = Bowling | first19 = T. J. | last20 = Carcich | first20 = B. T. | last21 = Collins | first21 = S. M. | last22 = Farnham | first22 = T. L. | last23 = Groussin | first23 = O. | last24 = Hermalyn | first24 = B. | last25 = Kelley | first25 = M. S. | last26 = Kelley | first26 = M. S. | last27 = Li | first27 = J. -Y. | last28 = Lindler | first28 = D. J. | last29 = Lisse | first29 = C. M. | last30 = McLaughlin | first30 = S. A. | title = EPOXI at Comet Hartley 2 | journal = Science | volume = 332 | issue = 6036 | pages = 1396–1400 | year = 2011 | pmid = 21680835 | doi = 10.1126/science.1204054|bibcode = 2011Sci...332.1396A }} Early results of the observations show that the comet is powered by [[dry ice]], not water vapor as was previously thought.The images were clear enough for scientists to link jets of dust and gas with specific surface features. "When comet Boethin could not be located, we went to our backup, which is every bit as interesting but about two years farther down the road," said Tom Duxbury, EPOXI project manager at NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory in Pasadena, California. "Hartley 2 is scientifically just as interesting as comet Boethin because both have relatively small, active nuclei," said [[Michael A'Hearn]], principal investigator for EPOXI at the University of Maryland, College Park.{{citation needed|date=November 2011}} ===Sundry opportunities=== In November 2010, EPOXI was used to make some test-training deep sky observations, using the MRI camera that is optimised for cometary imagery. Images were made of the [[Dumbbell Nebula|Dumbbell Nebula (M27)]], the [[Veil Nebula|Veil Nebula (NGC6960)]] and the [[Whirlpool Galaxy|Whirlpool Galaxy (M51a)]].[http://stardustnext.jpl.nasa.gov/mission/deepSkyObservation.html Deep Sky Feasibility Demonstration], [[NASA]], accessed 7 December 2011 == References == {{reflist|2}} == External links == {{commonscat|EPOXI}} {{Externalimage |align=right |width=300px |image1=[http://epoxi.umd.edu/3gallery/graphics/DI_EPOXI_orbit_nov4-lg.png Deep Impact trajectory] }} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20080509154729/http://epoxi.umd.edu/ EPOXI] home page * [http://www.nasa.gov/epoxi NASA's EPOXI] page * [http://www.spaceref.com/news/viewpr.html?pid=24719 NASA's Deep Impact Begins Hunt For Alien Worlds - 8 Feb 2008] * [http://epoxi.umd.edu/4gallery/Earth-Moon_vid.shtml Movie of the Moon transiting the Earth] {{Planetary Missions Program Office|Discovery=y}} {{Asteroid spacecraft}} {{Exoplanet search projects}} [[Category:Missions to comets]] [[Category:Discovery Program]] [[Category:Exoplanet search projects]] [[ru:Дип Импакт (КА)#EPOXI — расширенная миссия]]

{{pp-pc1|small=yes}} {{Infobox alternative medical diagnosis |name = Electromagnetic hypersensitivity |synonyms = Idiopathic environmental intolerance attributed to electromagnetic fields (IEI-EMF),
Electrohypersensitivity,
Electro-sensitivity,
Electrical sensitivity (ES),
Wi-Fi allergy |image = |caption = |field = [[Psychiatry]], [[Neurology]] |NCCIH = |school = |risks = |legality = |MeshID =}} {{Alternative medicine sidebar}} '''Electromagnetic hypersensitivity''' ('''EHS''') is a claimed sensitivity to [[electromagnetic fields]], to which negative symptoms are attributed. EHS has no scientific basis and is not a recognised [[medical diagnosis]]. Claims are characterized by a "variety of non-specific symptoms, which afflicted individuals attribute to exposure to [[electromagnetic field]]s".{{cite web|url= http://www.who.int/peh-emf/publications/facts/fs296/en/ |title= Electromagnetic fields and public health: Electromagnetic Hypersensitivity|publisher= World Health Organisation (WHO) |work= WHO Factsheet 296|date=December 2005|accessdate= 2012-10-24}} Those who are self-described with EHS report adverse reactions to electromagnetic fields at intensities well below the maximum levels permitted by international [[Mobile phone radiation and health#Safety standards and licensing|radiation safety standards]]. The majority of [[Provocation (medical)|provocation trials]] to date have found that such claimants are unable to distinguish between exposure and non-exposure to electromagnetic fields. A systematic review in 2005 showed no convincing scientific evidence for symptoms being caused by electromagnetic fields. Since then, several [[Blind experiment#Double-blind trials|double-blind experiments]] have shown that people who report electromagnetic hypersensitivity are unable to detect the presence of electromagnetic fields and are as likely to report ill health following a sham exposure as they are following exposure to genuine electromagnetic fields, suggesting the cause in these cases to be the [[nocebo|nocebo effect]].{{Cite journal|vauthors=Wilén J, Johansson A, Kalezic N, Lyskov E, Sandström M |title= Psychophysiological tests and provocation of subjects with mobile phone related symptoms |journal= Bioelectromagnetics. |volume= 27|issue=3 |pages=204–14 |year=2006 |pmid=16304699 |doi= 10.1002/bem.20195|url= }} A 2005 review by the UK [[Health Protection Agency]] and a 2006 systematic review each evaluated the evidence for various medical, psychological, behavioral, and alternative treatments for EHS and each found that the evidence-base was limited and not generalizable, but that the best evidence favored [[cognitive behavioural therapy]]. As of 2005, [[WHO]] recommended that people presenting with claims of EHS be evaluated to determine if they have a medical condition that may be causing the symptoms the person is attributing to EHS, that they have a psychological evaluation, and that the person's environment be evaluated for issues like air or [[noise pollution]] that may be causing problems. Some people who feel they are sensitive to electromagnetic fields may seek to reduce their exposure or use [[alternative medicine]]. Government agencies have enforced false advertising claims against companies selling devices to shield against EM radiation.{{cite web|last1=Fair|first1=Lesley|title=Federal Trade Commission Advertising Enforcement|url=https://www.ftc.gov/sites/default/files/attachments/training-materials/enforcement.pdf|publisher=Federal Trade Commission|pages=18–19|date=March 1, 2008}} ==Signs and symptoms== There are no specific symptoms associated with claims of EHS and reported symptoms range widely between individuals. They include headache, fatigue, stress, sleep disturbances, skin prickling, burning sensations and rashes, pain and ache in muscles and many other health problems. In severe cases such symptoms can be a real and sometimes disabling problem for the affected person, causing psychological distress. There is no scientific basis to link such symptoms to electromagnetic field exposure. The prevalence of some reported symptoms is geographically or culturally dependent and does not imply "a causal relationship between symptoms and attributed exposure".[http://www.hpa.org.uk/Publications/Radiation/HPARPDSeriesReports/HpaRpd010/ "Definition, epidemiology and management of electrical sensitivity"], Irvine, N, Report for the Radiation Protection Division of the UK Health Protection Agency, HPA-RPD-010, 2005{{cite web |last=Sage |first=Cindy |title=Microwave And Radiofrequency Radiation Exposure: A Growing Environmental Health Crisis? |work= |publisher=San Francisco Medical Society web page |url=http://www.sfms.org/AM/Template.cfm?Section=Home&template=/CM/HTMLDisplay.cfm&ContentID=1770 |doi= |accessdate=2008-05-31 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080515232743/http://www.sfms.org/AM/Template.cfm?Section=Home&template=%2FCM%2FHTMLDisplay.cfm&ContentID=1770 |archivedate=2008-05-15 |df= }} Many such reported symptoms overlap with other syndromes known as [[Medically unexplained physical symptoms|symptom-based conditions]], [[Somatization disorder|functional somatic syndromes]], and IEI ([[Multiple chemical sensitivity|idiopathic environmental intolerance]]). Those reporting electromagnetic hypersensitivity will usually describe different levels of susceptibility to [[electric field]]s, [[magnetic field]]s, and various frequencies of [[electromagnetic waves]]. Devices implicated include fluorescent and low-energy lights, [[mobile phone|mobile]], [[cordless phone|cordless/portable phones]], and [[Wi-Fi]].Philips, Alasdair and Jean (2003–2011). [http://www.emfields.org/library.asp Electromagnetic hypersensitivity (EHS) (in 8 sections)] A 2001 survey found that people self-diagnosing as EHS related their symptoms most frequently to [[mobile phone base station]]s (74%), followed by [[mobile phone]]s (36%), [[cordless phone]]s (29%), and [[power line]]s (27%).{{Cite journal| last=Röösli |first=Martin |author2=M Moser |author3=Y Baldinini |author4=M Meier |author5=C Braun-Fahrländer |title=Symptoms of ill health ascribed to electromagnetic field exposure – a questionnaire survey |journal=Int J Hyg Environ Health |volume=207 |issue=2 |pages=141–50 |date=February 2004 |pmid=15031956 |doi=10.1078/1438-4639-00269}} Surveys of electromagnetic hypersensitivity sufferers have not been able to find any consistent pattern to these symptoms.{{Cite journal| last = Hillert | first = L | authorlink = |author2=N Berglind |author3=BB Arnetz |author4=T Bellander | title = Prevalence of self-reported hypersensitivity to electric or magnetic fields in a population-based questionnaire survey | journal = Scand J Work Environ Health | volume = 28 | issue = 1 | pages = 33–41 | publisher = |date=February 2002 | pmid=11871850 | doi=10.5271/sjweh.644}} ==Causes== Most blinded conscious provocation studies have failed to show a correlation between exposure and symptoms, leading to the suggestion that psychological mechanisms play a role in causing or exacerbating EHS symptoms. In 2010, Rubin et al. published a follow-up to their 2005 review, bringing the totals to 46 double-blind experiments and 1175 individuals with self-diagnosed hypersensitivity.{{Cite journal|vauthors=Rubin GJ, Das Munshi J, Wessely S |title=Electromagnetic hypersensitivity: a systematic review of provocation studies |journal=Psychosom Med |volume=67 |issue=2 |pages=224–32 |year=2005 |pmid=15784787 |doi=10.1097/01.psy.0000155664.13300.64 |url= }}{{Cite journal|author1=James Rubin |author2=Rosa Nieto-Hernandez |author3=Simon Wessely | title = Idiopathic Environmental Intolerance Attributed to Electromagnetic Fields | journal = Bioelectromagnetics | volume = 31 | issue = 1 | pages = 1–11 |date= 2010 | pmid=19681059 | doi = 10.1002/bem.20536 }} Both reviews found no robust evidence to support the hypothesis that electromagnetic exposure causes EHS, as have other studies.{{Cite journal|author1=Sabine Regel |author2=Sonja Negovetic |author3=Martin Röösli |author4=Veronica Berdiñas |author5=Jürgen Schuderer |author6=Anke Huss |author7=Urs Lott |author8=Niels Kuster |author9=Peter Achermann |title=UMTS Base Station-like Exposure, Well-Being, and Cognitive Performance |journal=Environ Health Perspect |volume=114 |issue=8 |pages=1270–75 |date=August 2006 |url=http://www.ehponline.org/members/2006/8934/8934.html |doi=10.1289/ehp.8934 |pmid=16882538 |pmc=1552030 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071010073038/http://www.ehponline.org/members/2006/8934/8934.html |archivedate=2007-10-10 |df= }}{{Cite journal|author1=J Rubin |author2=G Hahn |author3=BS Everitt |author4=AJ Clear |author5=Simon Wessely | title = Are some people sensitive to mobile phone signals? Within participants double blind randomised provocation study | journal = British Medical Journal | issue = 7546 | pages = 886–89 |year=2006 | url = http://www.bmj.com/cgi/content/full/332/7546/886 | doi = 10.1136/bmj.38765.519850.55 | volume = 332 | pmid = 16520326 | pmc = 1440612 }} They also concluded that the studies supported the role of the [[nocebo]] effect in triggering acute symptoms in those with EHS.{{Cite journal|author=Röösli M |title=Radiofrequency electromagnetic field exposure and non-specific symptoms of ill health: a systematic review |journal=Environ. Res. |volume=107 |issue=2 |pages=277–87 |date= 2008 |pmid=18359015 |doi=10.1016/j.envres.2008.02.003 |url=}} Some other types of studies suggest evidence for symptoms at non-thermal levels of electromagnetic exposure. A review in 2010 of ten studies on neurobehavioral and cancer outcomes near cell phone base stations found eight with increased prevalence, including sleep disturbance and headaches.{{Cite journal|vauthors=Khurana VG, Hardell L, Everaert J, Bortkiewicz A, Carlberg M, Ahonen M |title= Epidemiological evidence for a health risk from mobile phone base stations |journal= Int J Occup Environ Health. |volume= 16|issue= 3|pages=263–67 |year= |pmid=20662418 |doi=10.1179/107735210799160192 |url= }} Since 1962, the [[microwave auditory effect]] or tinnitus has been shown from radio frequency exposure at levels below significant heating.{{Cite journal|author= Frey AH|title= Human auditory system response to modulated electromagnetic energy |journal= J Appl Physiol |volume=17 |issue=4 |pages= 689–92|year= 1962|pmid= 13895081|doi= |url= }}{{Cite journal|vauthors=Hutter HP, Moshammer H, Wallner P, Cartellieri M, Denk-Linnert DM, Katzinger M, Ehrenberger K, Kundi M |title= Tinnitus and mobile phone use |journal= Occup Environ Med |volume= 67|issue= 12|pages=804–08 |year= 2010|pmid= 20573849|doi= 10.1136/oem.2009.048116|url= }} Studies during the 1960s in Europe and Russia claimed to show effects on humans, especially the nervous system, from low energy RF radiation; the studies were disputed at the time.{{Citation |author=Bergman W |title= The Effect of Microwaves on the Central Nervous System (trans. from German)| pages= 1–77|year= 1965|publisher= Ford Motor Company|doi= |url=http://www.magdahavas.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2010/12/German_Ford_Motor_company_The_Effect_of_Microwaves_on_The_Central_Nervous_System.pdf}}{{cite book|last1=Michaelson|first1=Sol M.|editor1-last=Calvin|editor1-first=Melvin|editor2-last=Gazenko|editor2-first=Oleg G|date=1975|title=Ecological and Physiological Bases of Space Biology and Medicine|publisher=NASA Scientific and Technical lnformation Office | location=Washington, D.C.|pages=409–52|url=https://ntrs.nasa.gov/archive/nasa/casi.ntrs.nasa.gov/19760019731.pdf|format=Volume II Book 2 of Foundations of Space Biology and Medicine|chapter=Radio-Frequency and Microwave Energies, Magnetic and Electric Fields}}{{rp|427–30}} Other studies on sensitivity have looked at therapeutic procedures using non-thermal electromagnetic exposure,{{Cite journal|author= Pilla AA |title= Nonthermal electromagnetic fields: from first messenger to therapeutic applications |journal= Electromagn Biol Med. |volume= 32|issue= 2|pages=123–36 |year= 2013|pmid= 23675615|doi=10.3109/15368378.2013.776335 |url= }} genetic factors,{{Cite journal|vauthors=De Luca C, Chung Sheun Thai J, Raskovic D, Cesareo E, Caccamo D, Trukhanov A, Korkina L |title= Metabolic and genetic screening of electromagnetic hypersensitive subjects as a feasible tool for diagnostics and intervention |journal= Mediators Inflamm. |volume=2014 |issue= 924184 |pages= 1–14|year= |pmid=24812443 |doi=10.1155/2014/924184 |pmc=4000647}} an alteration in mast cells, oxidative stress, protein expression and voltage-gated calcium channels.{{Cite journal|vauthors=Johansson O, Gangi S, Liang Y, Yoshimura K, Jing C, Liu PY |title= Cutaneous mast cells are altered in normal healthy volunteers sitting in front of ordinary TVs/PCs – results from open-field provocation experiments |journal= J Cutan Pathol. |volume= 28|issue=10 |pages=513–39 |year=2001 |pmid=11737520 |doi=10.1034/j.1600-0560.2001.281004.x |url= }}{{Cite journal|author= Pall ML |title= Electromagnetic fields act via activation of voltage-gated calcium channels to produce beneficial or adverse effects |journal= J Cell Mol Med|volume=17 |issue=8 |pages= 958–65|year= 2013|pmid= 23802593|doi=10.1111/jcmm.12088 |pmc=3780531}} Mercury release from dental amalgam and heavy metal toxicity have also been implicated in exposure effects and symptoms.{{Cite journal|vauthors=Mortazavi SM, Daiee E, Yazdi A, Khiabani K, Kavousi A, Vazirinejad R, Behnejad B, Ghasemi M, Mood MB |title= Mercury release from dental amalgam restorations after magnetic resonance imaging and following mobile phone use |journal= Pak J Biol Sci. |volume= 11|issue= 8|pages=1142–46 |year=2008 |pmid=18819554 |doi= 10.3923/pjbs.2008.1142.1146|url= }} Another line of study has been the nature of hyper-sensitivity or intolerance and the range of environmental exposures which may be related to it. Some 80% of people with self-diagnosed electromagnetic intolerance also claim intolerance to low levels of chemical exposure.{{Cite journal|vauthors=Nordin S, Neely G, Olsson D, Sandström M |title= Odor and Noise Intolerance in Persons with Self-Reported Electromagnetic Hypersensitivity |journal= Int J Environ Res Public Health |volume= 11|issue= 9|pages= 8794–805|year=2014 |pmid=25166918 |doi=10.3390/ijerph110908794 |pmc=4198991}}{{Cite journal|vauthors=Genuis SJ, Lipp CT |title= Electromagnetic hypersensitivity: fact or fiction?|journal= Sci Total Environ|volume= 414|issue= |pages=103–12 |year= 2012|pmid=22153604 |doi=10.1016/j.scitotenv.2011.11.008 |url= }} ==Diagnosis== Electromagnetic hypersensitivity is not an accepted diagnosis; medically there is no case definition or clinical practice guideline and there is no specific test to identify it, nor is there an agreed-upon definition with which to conduct clinical research.{{cite journal |vauthors=Baliatsas C, Van Kamp I, Lebret E, Rubin GJ |title=Idiopathic environmental intolerance attributed to electromagnetic fields (IEI-EMF): a systematic review of identifying criteria |journal=BMC Public Health |volume=12 |issue= |page=643 |year=2012 |pmid=22883305 |pmc=3504528 |doi=10.1186/1471-2458-12-643 |type=Systematic review}} Complaints of electromagnetic hypersensitivity may mask organic or psychiatric illness. Diagnosis of those underlying conditions involves investigating and identifying possible known medical causes of any symptoms observed. It may require both a thorough medical evaluation to identify and treat any specific conditions that may be responsible for the symptoms, and a psychological evaluation to identify alternative psychiatric/psychological conditions that may be responsible or contribute to the symptoms.{{Cite journal|vauthors=Rubin GJ, Cleare AJ, Wessely S |title=Psychological factors associated with self-reported sensitivity to mobile phones |journal=J Psychosom Res |volume=64 |issue=1 |pages=1–9; discussion 11–2 |date=January 2008 |pmid=18157992 |doi=10.1016/j.jpsychores.2007.05.006 |url=}} Symptoms may also be brought on by imagining that exposure is causing harm, an example of the [[nocebo effect]]. Studies have shown that reports of symptoms are more closely associated with belief that one is being exposed than with any actual exposure.{{Skeptoid|id=4072|number=72|title=Electromagnetic Hypersensitivity: Real or Imagined?|accessdate=27 December 2016|quote="The ability of a human brain to convince itself of just about anything is not to be underestimated. If you believe yourself to be electrosensitive, then you will be, quite literally, whenever you (think that you) perceive the presence of electromagnetism... you will actually suffer measurable physical symptoms and can potentially become acutely ill."}} ==Management== A 2006 systematic review and a 2005 review by the UK Health Protection Agency each evaluated the evidence for various medical, psychological, behavioral, and alternative treatments for EHS and each found that the evidence-base was limited and not generalizable.{{Cite journal|vauthors=Rubin GJ, Das Munshi J, Wessely S |title=A systematic review of treatments for electromagnetic hypersensitivity |journal=Psychother Psychosom |volume=75 |issue=1 |pages=12–18 |year=2006 |pmid=16361870 |doi=10.1159/000089222}} The conclusion of the 2006 review stated: "The evidence base concerning treatment options for electromagnetic hypersensitivity is limited and more research is needed before any definitive clinical recommendations can be made. However, the best evidence currently available suggests that cognitive behavioural therapy is effective for patients who report being hypersensitive to weak electromagnetic fields." As of 2005, WHO recommended that people presenting with claims of EHS be evaluated to determine if they have a medical condition that may be causing the symptoms the person is attributing to EHS, that they have a psychological evaluation, and that the person's environment be evaluated for issues like air or noise pollution that may be causing problems. ==Prevalence== The prevalence of claimed electromagnetic hypersensitivity has been estimated as being between a few cases per million to 5% of the population depending on the location and definition of the condition. In 2002, a [[questionnaire]] survey of 2,072 people in California found that the prevalence of self-reported electromagnetic hypersensitivity within the sample group was 3% (95% CI 2.8–3.68%), with electromagnetic hypersensitivity being defined as "being allergic or very sensitive to getting near electrical appliances, computers, or power lines" (response rate 58.3%).{{Cite journal | last = Levallois | first = P | authorlink = |author2=R Neutra |author3=G Lee |author4=L Hristova | title = Study of self-reported hypersensitivity to electromagnetic fields in California | journal = Environ Health Perspect | volume = 110 | issue = Suppl 4 | pages = 619–23 | publisher = |date=August 2002 | pmid=12194896 | doi =10.1289/ehp.02110s4619 | id = | pmc = 1241215 }} A similar questionnaire survey from the same year in Stockholm County (Sweden), found a 1.5% prevalence of self-reported electromagnetic hypersensitivity within the sample group, with electromagnetic hypersensitivity being defined as "hypersensitivity or allergy to electric or magnetic fields" (response rate 73%). A 2004 survey in Switzerland found a 5% prevalence of claimed electromagnetic hypersensitivity in the sample group of 2,048.{{Cite journal|vauthors=Schreier N, Huss A, Röösli M |title=The prevalence of symptoms attributed to electromagnetic field exposure: a cross-sectional representative survey in Switzerland |journal=Soz Praventivmed |volume=51 |issue=4 |pages=202–09 |year=2006 |pmid=17193782 |doi=10.1007/s00038-006-5061-2}} In 2007, a UK survey aimed at a randomly selected group of 20,000 people found a prevalence of 4% for symptoms self-attributed to electromagnetic exposure.{{Cite journal |vauthors=Eltiti S, Wallace D, Zougkou K, etal |title=Development and evaluation of the electromagnetic hypersensitivity questionnaire |journal=Bioelectromagnetics |volume=28 |issue=2 |pages=137–51 |date=February 2007 |pmid=17013888 |doi=10.1002/bem.20279}} A group of scientists also attempted to estimate the number of people reporting "subjective symptoms" from electromagnetic fields for the [[European Commission]].{{Cite journal | last = Bergqvist | first = U | authorlink = | first2 = E |last2=Vogel |first3=L |last3=Aringer |first4=J |last4=Cunningham |first5=F |last5=Gobba |first6=N |last6=Leitgeb |first7=L |last7=Miro |first8=G |last8=Neubauer |first9=I |last9=Ruppe |first10=P |last10=Vecchia |first11=C |last11=Wadman | title = Possible health implications of subjective symptoms and electromagnetic fields. A report prepared by a European group of experts for the European Commission, DG V | journal = Arbete och Hälsa | volume = 19 | issue = | pages = | publisher = |year=1997 | url = https://gupea.ub.gu.se/dspace/handle/2077/4156 | doi = | id = | accessdate = }} In the words of a HPA review, they concluded that "the differences in prevalence were at least partly due to the differences in available information and media attention around electromagnetic hypersensitivity that exist in different countries. Similar views have been expressed by other commentators." ==Society and culture== In 2010, a cell tower operator in [[South Africa]] revealed at a public meeting that the tower that nearby residents were blaming for their current EHS symptoms had been turned off over six weeks prior to the meeting, thus making it a highly unlikely cause of EHS symptoms.{{cite news|title=Massive revelation in iBurst tower battle|url=https://mybroadband.co.za/news/wireless/11099-massive-revelation-in-iburst-tower-battle.html|accessdate=31 December 2016}}{{cite news|title=Electrosensitives tortured by a radio tower that had been switched off for six weeks|url=http://boingboing.net/2010/01/15/electrosensitives-to.html|accessdate=31 December 2016}} In February 2014, the [[United Kingdom|UK]] [[Advertising Standards Authority (United Kingdom)|Advertising Standards Authority]] found that claims of harm from electromagnetic radiation, made in a product advertisement, were unsubstantiated and misleading.{{cite web|title=ASA Ruling on The Healthy House Ltd|url=https://www.asa.org.uk/Rulings/Adjudications/2014/2/The-Healthy-House-Ltd/SHP_ADJ_248892.aspx#.WBfvIeErKV4|publisher=UK Advertising Standards Authority|date=19 February 2014}} People have filed lawsuits to try to win damages due to harm claimed from electromagnetic radiation. In 2012, a New Mexico judge dismissed a lawsuit in which one person sued his neighbor, claiming to have been harmed by EM radiation from his neighbor's cordless telephones, dimmer switches, chargers, Wi-Fi and other devices. The plaintiff brought the testimony of his doctor, who also believed she had EHS, and a person who represented himself as a neurotoxicologist; the judge found none of their testimony credible.{{cite web|last1=Barrett|first1=Stephen|title="Electromagnetic Hypersensitivity" Is Not a Valid Diagnosis|url=http://www.quackwatch.org/01QuackeryRelatedTopics/ems.html|publisher=Quackwatch|accessdate=1 November 2016|date=August 28, 2015}} In 2015, parents of a boy at a school in [[Southborough, Massachusetts|Southborough]], [[Massachusetts]] alleged that the school's Wi-Fi was making the boy sick.{{cite news|last1=O'Connell|first1=Scott|title=Wi-Fi lawsuit against Southboro's Fay School is headed to trial |url=http://www.telegram.com/article/20160118/NEWS/160119173 |work=The Telegram |date=January 18, 2016}} In November 2015, a depressed teenage girl in England committed suicide. Her suicide was attributed to EHS by her parents and taken up by tabloids and EHS advocates.{{cite journal|last1=Gorski|first1=David|title="Electromagnetic hypersensitivity" and "wifi allergies": Bogus diagnoses with tragic real world consequences|journal=Science-Based Medicine|date=December 7, 2015|url=https://www.sciencebasedmedicine.org/electromagnetic-hypersensitivity-and-wifi-allergies-bogus-diagnoses-with-tragic-real-world-consequences/}} Some people who feel they are sensitive to electromagnetic fields self-treat by trying to reduce their exposure to electromagnetic sources by avoiding sources of exposure, disconnecting or removing electrical devices, shielding or screening of self or residence, and [[alternative medicine]]. In [[Sweden]], some municipalities provide [[disability]] grants to people who claim to have EHS in order to have abatement work done in their homes even though the public health authority does not recognize EHS as an actual medical condition; towns in [[Halland]] do not provide such funds and this decision was challenged and upheld in court.{{cite journal|last1=Johansson|first1=O|title=Electrohypersensitivity: a functional impairment due to an inaccessible environment.|journal=Reviews on environmental health|date=2015|volume=30|issue=4|pages=311–21|doi=10.1515/reveh-2015-0018|pmid=26613327}}{{cite news|title=Inga bidrag ges till elsanering i Halland – P4 Halland|url=http://sverigesradio.se/sida/artikel.aspx?programid=128&artikel=1509864|work=Sveriges Radio|date=31 July 2007|language=Swedish}}{{cite web|title=Kommuner erbjuder fortfarande elsanering|url=https://www.svt.se/nyheter/inrikes/kommuner-ger-fortfarande-kontroversiellt-bidrag|website=svt.se|accessdate=8 June 2017}} The [[United States National Radio Quiet Zone]] is an area where wireless signals are restricted for scientific research purposes, and some people who believe they have EHS have relocated there seeking relief.{{cite news | url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-14887428 | title = 'Wi-fi refugees' shelter in West Virginia mountains | first = Jane | last = O'Brien | first2= Matt | last2= Danzico |date = September 12, 2011 | publisher = BBC News | accessdate = September 13, 2011}}{{cite news|url=http://www.slate.com/articles/technology/future_tense/2013/04/green_bank_w_v_where_the_electrosensitive_can_escape_the_modern_world.single.html|title=Green Bank, W.V., where the electrosensitive can escape the modern world. |last=Stromberg|first=Joseph|date=12 April 2013|work=[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]]|accessdate=14 April 2013}}{{cite news|url=http://www.washingtonian.com/articles/people/the-town-without-wi-fi/?src=longreads&mc_cid=211af0517e&mc_eid=290a0d1dfd|title=The Town Without Wi-Fi|last=Gaynor|first=Michael|date=January 2015|work=[[Washingtonian (magazine)|Washingtonian]]|accessdate=12 January 2015}} [[Gro Harlem Brundtland]], former [[prime minister]] of [[Norway]] and [[Director general]] of the [[World Health Organization]], claims to suffer from EHS.Aud Dalsegg; [https://www.dagbladet.no/nyheter/far-hodesmerter-av-mobilstraling/65792704 Får hodesmerter av mobilstråling], ''Daglbadet'', 9 March 2002 (In Norwegian). (retrieved 1 May 2018) In 2015 she said that she had been sensitive for 25 years.{{Cite news|author=Karen Tjernshaugen |title= Brundtland: - Min kropp har reagert på mobilstråling i 25 år |url=https://www.aftenposten.no/norge/i/VL6W/Brundtland---Min-kropp-har-reagert-pa-mobilstraling-i-25-ar|newspaper=Aftenposten |date= 14 August 2015 |language= Norwegian |accessdate=1 May 2018}} In the fictional television [[crime drama]] ''[[Better Call Saul]]'', the character [[Chuck McGill|Charles "Chuck" McGill]] is depicted as experiencing the symptoms of EHS. In the episode ''[[Alpine Shepherd Boy]]'', a skeptical doctor surreptitiously operates a switch controlling the electronics in Chuck's hospital bed. This does not affect his symptoms, suggesting that his electromagnetic hypersensitivity is not genuine.{{Cite episode |title=Alpine Shepherd Boy|episode-link=Alpine Shepherd Boy|series= Better Call Saul|series-link=Better Call Saul|network=AMC|date=March 2, 2015|season=1|number=5|minutes=44|language=English}} A similar instance of Chuck's symptoms being objectively [[psychosomatic]] is seen on the episode ''[[Chicanery (Better Call Saul)|Chicanery]]''.{{Cite episode |title=Chicanery|episode-link=Chicanery (Better Call Saul)|series= Better Call Saul|series-link=Better Call Saul|network=AMC|date=May 8, 2017|season=3|number=5|minutes=49|language=English}} Although a fully charged cellphone battery is planted on his person without his knowledge,[http://m.emmys.com/sites/default/files/collateral/bettercallsaul_chicanery%20Final-ATAS.pdf Script of Episode, Chicanery] Chuck experiences no adverse effects by having an electronic device on his body for close to two hours. When this fact is revealed to him, he is profoundly shaken, and comes to see "beyond a shadow of a doubt"{{Cite episode |title=Slip|episode-link=Slip (Better Call Saul)|series= Better Call Saul|series-link=Better Call Saul|network=AMC|date=June 5, 2017|season=3|number=8|minutes=48|language=English}} that his symptoms are an indication of mental disease spurred on by past emotional trauma,[https://www.springfieldspringfield.co.uk/view_episode_scripts.php?tv-show=better-call-saul-2015&episode=s03e08 Script of Episode, Slip] rather than EHS. ==See also== * [[Arthur Firstenberg]] * [[Bioelectromagnetics]] * [[Electromagnetic radiation and health]] * [[List of questionable diseases]] * [[Wireless electronic devices and health]] ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} == External links == * [https://www.arpansa.gov.au/research-and-expertise/technical-reports/radiofrequency-electromagnetic-energy-and-health-research Radiofrequency Electromagnetic Energy and Health:Research Needs] from the [[Australian Radiation Protection and Nuclear Safety Agency]] (ARPANSA) {{Pseudoscience|state=collapsed}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Electromagnetic Hypersensitivity}} [[Category:Alternative diagnoses]] [[Category:Somatic psychology]] [[Category:Pseudoscience]]

revision.comment: /* top */[[User:JCW-CleanerBot#Logic|task]], replaced: Philos. Trans. R. Soc. Lond., B, Biol. Sci. → Philos. Trans. R. Soc. Lond. B Biol. Sci. using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]

revision.text:
An '''exeligmos''' ({{lang-el|ἐξέλιγμος}} — ''turning of the wheel'') is a period of 54 years, 33 days that can be used to predict successive [[eclipse]]s with similar properties and location. For a [[solar eclipse]], after every exeligmos a solar eclipse of similar characteristics will occur in a location close to the eclipse before it. For a [[lunar eclipse]] the same part of the earth will view an eclipse that is very similar to the one that occurred one exeligmos before it (see main text for visual examples). It is an [[eclipse cycle]] that is a triple [[saros (astronomy)|saros]], 3 saroses (or saroi) long, with the advantage that it has nearly an integer number of days so the next eclipse will be visible at locations and times near the eclipse that occurred one exeligmos earlier. In contrast, each saros, an eclipse occurs about 8 hours later in the day or about 120° to the west of the eclipse that occurred one saros earlier.{{cite book|last=Littman|display-authors=etal|first=Mark|title=Totality: eclipses of the sun|year=2008|publisher=[[Oxford University Press]]|isbn=0-19-953209-5|pages=325–326}} == Details == The Greeks had knowledge of the exeligmos by at latest 100 BC. A Greek astronomical clock called the [[Antikythera mechanism]] used epicyclic gearing to predict the dates of consecutive exeligmoses.{{Cite journal | author=Freeth, Tony |author2=Y. Bitsakis |author3=X. Moussas |author4=M.G. Edmunds | journal=Nature | volume=444 | pages=587–591 | date=November 30, 2006 | url=http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v444/n7119/abs/nature05357.html | title=Decoding the ancient Greek astronomical calculator known as the Antikythera Mechanism | doi=10.1038/nature05357 | pmid=17136087 | issue=7119 |bibcode = 2006Natur.444..587F }} The exeligmos is 669 [[month#Synodic month|synodic months]] (every eclipse cycle must be an integer number of synodic months), almost exactly 726 [[month#Draconic month|draconic months]] (which ensures the sun and moon are in alignment during the new moon), and also almost exactly 717 [[month#Anomalistic month|anomalistic months]]https://books.google.com/books?id=tAhZT5jRTwgC&pg=PA301&lpg=PA301&dq=exeligmos+717+669&source=bl&ots=sFcx9lkg0x&sig=RBi98OvhkiwSnAhaMBmI-upYh6M&hl=en&sa=X&ei=JgWbUOuNDqmQ0AWtnoGgCw&ved=0CCoQ6AEwAg#v=onepage&q&f=false (ensuring the moon is at the same point of its elliptic orbit). The first two factors make this a long lasting eclipse series. The latter factor is what makes each eclipse in an exeligmos so similar. The near integer number of anomalistic months ensures that the apparent diameter of the moon will be nearly the same with each successive eclipse. The fact that it is very nearly a whole integer of days ensures each successive eclipse in the series occurs very close to the previous eclipse in the series. For each successive eclipse in an exeligmos series the longitude and latitude can change significantly because an exeligmos is over a month longer than a calendar year, and the [[Gamma (eclipse)|gamma]] increases/decreases because an exeligmos is about three hours shorter than a draconic month. The sun's apparent diameter also changes significantly in one month, affecting the length and width of a solar eclipse. === Solar exeligmos example === Here is a comparison of two total solar eclipses one exeligmos apart: {| class="wikitable" |- align=center ! width="200px" | || [[Solar eclipse of March 7, 1970|March 7, 1970]] || [[Solar eclipse of April 8, 2024|April 8, 2024]] |- | Path Map
(total eclipse is blue path)
(green lines represent limits of partial eclipse) || [[File:1970-03-07 eclipse crop.png|220px]] || [[File:2024-04-08 eclipse crop.png|220px]] |- | Duration || 3 minutes 28 seconds || 4 minutes 28 seconds |- | Max width of total eclipse path || 153 kilometers|| 199 kilometers |- | Latitude of greatest eclipse || 18° North || 25° North |- | Time of greatest eclipse (UTC) || 17:38 || 18:17 |} === Lunar exeligmos example === Here is a comparison of two total lunar eclipses one exeligmos apart:
{| class="wikitable" |- align=center ! width="200px" | || [[February 1990 lunar eclipse|February 9, 1990]] || [[March 2044 lunar eclipse|March 13, 2044]] |- | Path Map
|| [[File:Lunar eclipse chart close-1990Feb09.png|220px]] || [[File:Lunar eclipse chart close-2044Mar13.png|220px]] |- | Visibility
(side of earth eclipse is visible from) || [[File:Lunar eclipse from moon-1990Feb09.png|220px]] || [[File:Lunar eclipse from moon-2044Mar13.png|220px]] |- | Duration (Partial eclipse)|| 204 minutes || 209 minutes |- | Time of greatest eclipse (UTC) || 19:12 || 19:38 |} == Sample series of solar exeligmos == Exeligmos table of [[solar saros 136]]. Each eclipse occurs at roughly the same longitude but moves about 5-15 degrees in latitude with each successive cycle. {| class=wikitable |- align=center !Saros||Member||DateGregorian Calendar is used for dates after 1582 Oct 15. ||[http://eclipse.gsfc.nasa.gov/5MCSEmap/2501-2600/2586-07-07.gif] |} == Solar Exeligmos Animation == Here is an animation of an exeligmos series. Note the similar paths of each total eclipse, and how they fall close to the same [[longitude]] of the earth.[http://eclipse.gsfc.nasa.gov/eclipse.html NASA Eclipse Website] Fred Espenak [[File:Exeligmos.gif|300px]] === Solar Saros Animation (for comparison) === This next animation is from the entire [[Solar saros 136|saros series]] of the exeligmos above. Notice how each eclipse falls on a different side of the earth (120 degrees apart). [[File:Saros 136 animation.gif]] ==See also== * [[Solar eclipse]] * [[Eclipse cycle]] * [[Saros (astronomy)|Saros]] * [[Full moon cycle]] == References == {{Reflist}} [[Category:Eclipses]] [[Category:Time in astronomy]]
